rRMTUx-y6.memHandModelNotes:
Aquatic species, only terrestrial systems selected apply to nesting habitat.  Flow Accumulation may be a good predictor for this species since it needs wider, moving rivers and streams.  Probably could set minimum threshold for accumulation, can't find any literature to support and type of slope,threshold etc., but in CP could probably use min of 5-10.  Amy Silvano 6jul05

Changed flowing interior buffer from 0m to 120m. MJR 30 January 2008.

habitat_description:
The ringed map turtle is restricted to the Pearl River drainage system. Its distribution extends from Philadelphia, Neshoba County, Mississippi in the Ross Barnett Reservoir, West Pearl rivers, and into the town of Pearl River, Louisiana. Also found in the lower Bogue Chitto River, Louisiana (McCoy and Vogt 1988 (As referenced by Natureserve.org). Highest densities occur in the Pearl River in the portion above Ross Barnett Reservoir and in localities of Simpson County (Dundee and Rossman 1989; Ernst et al. 1994; Matthews and Moseley 1990). This species does not occur in tributaries or tidal areas. The main food sources depend on high water quality. This benthic species burrow in or using soil, fallen logs, and leaf litter. Eggs are usually laid on gravel bars and sandy beaches (Natureserve.org).

The rivers and streams this species occupies are characterized by moderate gradient, but also somewhat fast currents. Its riparian distribution is restricted to sand dunes. This species is prevalent in fast current streams with plenty of logs or other basking or hiding opportunities. Surrounding areas of rivers are sandy or that include gravel bars (Dickerson and Reine 1996; McCoy and Vogt 1980; Natureserve.org).

*Map turtles live in riverine-riparian systems and associated floodplain lakes, ponds, and sloughs. Often they nest on sandy banks or sand bars but sometimes up to about 100 m from water (Natureserve.org)
